name: Literary Classics
description: Memorable lines from the greatest works of literature throughout history.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.
quotes.notes: Opening line of the novel. One of the most famous first lines in English literature, establishing the novel's ironic tone.

quotes.content: All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.
quotes.notes: Opening line of the novel. Known as the 'Anna Karenina principle' in fields from evolutionary biology to business.

quotes.content: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.
quotes.source: A Tale of Two Cities, Book 1, Chapter 1 (1859)
quotes.notes: Opening line of the novel set during the French Revolution. The full first sentence continues for 119 words.

quotes.content: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.
quotes.notes: The novel's famous closing line. Encapsulates the theme of pursuing an unattainable dream.

quotes.content: All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.
quotes.source: The Fellowship of the Ring, Book 1, Chapter 2 (1954)
quotes.notes: Gandalf's words to Frodo in Moria. One of the most quoted passages from The Lord of the Rings.

quotes.content: It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.
quotes.source: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, Chapter 18 (1998)
quotes.notes: Dumbledore's words to Harry in the Chamber of Secrets. A central theme of the Harry Potter series.

quotes.content: Whatever our souls are made of, his and mine are the same.
quotes.notes: Catherine Earnshaw speaking about Heathcliff. Expresses the intense, almost supernatural connection between them.

quotes.content: To be, or not to be: that is the question.
quotes.notes: Beginning of Hamlet's famous soliloquy on existence. Perhaps the most famous line in English literature.

quotes.content: Call me Ishmael.
quotes.notes: Opening line of the novel. One of literature's most recognizable first lines, establishing the narrator's identity.

quotes.content: It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen.
quotes.notes: Opening line immediately signals a world where things are not as they should be. The 13-hour clock suggests totalitarian control.

quotes.content: In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I've been turning over in my mind ever since.
quotes.notes: Opening line introducing Nick Carraway as narrator. Sets up the novel's themes of judgment and moral complexity.

quotes.content: All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others.
quotes.notes: The pigs' final corruption of the original Seven Commandments. A satirical critique of Soviet communism.

quotes.content: It is nothing to die; it is frightful not to live.
quotes.notes: From Jean Valjean's reflections near the novel's end. Expresses the theme of redemption through living fully.

quotes.content: There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.
quotes.source: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1969)
quotes.notes: From Angelou's autobiography about her childhood. Reflects the importance of voice and storytelling in healing.

quotes.content: One must imagine Sisyphus happy.
quotes.source: The Myth of Sisyphus, final line (1942)
quotes.notes: Concluding line of Camus' philosophical essay. Suggests finding meaning in struggle despite absurdity.

quotes.content: I took a deep breath and listened to the old brag of my heart: I am, I am, I am.
quotes.notes: Esther Greenwood's moment of reconnection with life. Represents recovery and the persistence of being.

quotes.content: In spite of everything, I still believe that people are really good at heart.
quotes.source: The Diary of a Young Girl (July 15, 1944)
quotes.notes: Written while hiding from the Nazis. Remarkable optimism given her circumstances; she died in Bergen-Belsen.

quotes.content: Not all those who wander are lost.
quotes.source: The Fellowship of the Ring, Book 1, Chapter 10 (1954)
quotes.notes: From the poem 'All that is gold does not glitter' about Aragorn. Often quoted independently of the novel.

quotes.content: Beware; for I am fearless, and therefore powerful.
quotes.notes: The creature's words to Victor Frankenstein. Warns of the danger of creating something one cannot control.

quotes.content: Who controls the past controls the future. Who controls the present controls the past.
quotes.notes: Party slogan in the novel. Describes how totalitarian regimes manipulate historical truth.

quotes.content: The only way out of the labyrinth of suffering is to forgive.
quotes.notes: Central theme of the novel. The labyrinth question is taken from Gabriel García Márquez's 'The General in His Labyrinth.'

quotes.content: Tomorrow is another day.
quotes.source: Gone with the Wind, final line (1936)
quotes.notes: Scarlett O'Hara's famous closing declaration. Represents resilience and hope despite loss.

quotes.content: We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars.
quotes.notes: Lord Darlington's line in the play. One of Wilde's most quoted aphorisms about aspiration despite circumstances.

quotes.content: There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
quotes.notes: Hamlet to Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. An early expression of cognitive philosophy about perception and reality.

quotes.content: Brave New World.
quotes.notes: Miranda's line 'O brave new world, that has such people in't!' Huxley used it ironically as his 1932 novel title.

quotes.content: Reader, I married him.
quotes.notes: Jane's direct address to the reader announcing her marriage to Rochester. Iconic for its simple directness.

quotes.content: Happiness can be found, even in the darkest of times, if one only remembers to turn on the light.
quotes.source: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, film adaptation (2004)
quotes.notes: Dumbledore's line from the film script by Steve Kloves, not the original novel. Widely attributed to J.K. Rowling but originated in the screenplay.

quotes.content: The past is never dead. It's not even past.
quotes.source: Requiem for a Nun, Act 1, Scene 3 (1951)
quotes.notes: Gavin Stevens' line. Reflects Faulkner's recurring theme of history's persistent influence on the present.

quotes.content: There is always some madness in love. But there is also always some reason in madness.
quotes.notes: From Zarathustra's discourses. Explores the irrational nature of love while acknowledging its internal logic.
